awd_abstract_narration:
Causality is a key aspect of cognition. Our minds bring order to the flux of experience by relating observed events to one another as causes and effects. This is an indispensible prerequisite to explaining past events and predicting future one. Philosophers and cognitive scientists have long puzzled over the cognitive basis of our ability to attribute cause-effect relations. A question of fundamental concern is which aspects of causal cognition are invariant across human populations and thus may have an innate basis, and which are learned and subject to cross-cultural variation. This project aims to contribute to answering this question, using primarily language as a window into causal cognition. The principal objective is the first large-scale comparison of how speakers of different languages categorize causal chains for the purposes of describing them. The project will help discern the criteria by which speakers choose from among the expressive options available to them when representing causal chains. These options have been shown to vary enormously across languages. Furthermore, the encoding of causal relations is a key aspect of the grammatical structure of human language, and the project will make important empirical contributions to the theory of the "syntax-semantics interface", the mapping between form and meaning in language. It also includes the largest-scale investigation to date of how language interfaces with nonlinguistic cognition in the representation of causality.

An international team of 28 experienced field researchers will investigate the representation of causality across 29 languages belonging to 26 language families and spoken on six continents. A large set of video clips depicting event sequences that may or may not be causally related will be created. Descriptions of these clips under various controlled conditions will be collected from at least 12 speakers per language. The researchers will probe the meaning and structure of the descriptions, testing crosslinguistic predictions in the process. A nonverbal categorization experiment will test how participants conceptualize causal relations when they do not talk about them, with the objective of studying to what degree internal thought and verbal representations of causality align.

por.por_cntn:
Causality is a key aspect of cognition. Our minds bring order to the flux of experience by relating observed events to one another as causes and effects. This is an indispensable prerequisite to explaining past events and predicting future one. Philosophers and cognitive scientists have long puzzled over the cognitive basis of our ability to attribute cause-effect relations. A question of fundamental concern is which aspects of causal cognition are invariant across human populations and thus may have an innate basis, and which are learned and subject to cross-cultural variation. The project Causality Across Languages (CAL) has aimed to contribute to answering this question, using primarily language as a window into causal cognition. The principal objective has been the first large-scale comparison of how speakers of different languages categorize causal chains for the purposes of describing them. The project has aimed to discern the criteria by which speakers choose from among the expressive options available to them when representing causal chains.

The CAL team?s first significant contribution toward answering this question was the development of a new method. A set of video clips was created to represent all possible combinations of the properties that previous research had suggested were relevant to the encoding of causal chains: whether the causer was an intentional or accidental human agent or a natural force, the nature of the caused event or action, whether a human participant was involved in the caused event or action, and if so, whether they had control over it. Descriptions of these clips were then recorded from speakers of languages of Africa, the Americas, Asia, and Europe. The expressions of causality of each language were extracted from these descriptions and a new set of stimulus utterances was created that generalized these types of expressions to all clips. Then, acceptability judgments were collected from a larger number of speakers of each language in order to determine which expressions were considered ideally fit for which scenes, and thus for which types of causal chains.

Previous research suggested that languages rely on an economy of expression, where simple expressions are used for stereotypical events and more complex ones for atypical events. For instance, we might say Sally stopped the car if she was driving and hit the brakes, but Sally caused the car to stop if she did something unusual to effect the outcome, such as step into the road in front of the car. The CAL team has conducted one of the first large-scale quantitative crosslinguistic tests of this hypothesis, and the one using the most varied sample of languages in terms of culture, geography, and grammatical features.

The team found the hypothesis confirmed, but discovered a new twist: whereas simple expressions such as She stopped the car are restricted in most languages to scenes in which a human agent effects an outcome directly, the meaning of complex expressions such as She caused the car to stop is not actually the mirror image of that, a scene in which an agent acts via another, intermediate agent. The semantics of such complex causatives turns out to be more diffuse.

Here, another methodological innovation came to fruition: the team developed a method for using machine learning tools of statistical classification to discover the ?semantic prototypes? of causative expressions, i.e., the scene types for which each type of expression is optimally suited. It emerged that whereas simple expressions tend to have a single prototype, usually involving unmediated physical impact, more complex causative expressions often have multiple prototypes, e.g., one involving an intermediate agent and another involving accidental causers or natural forces.

The CAL team also investigated the representation of causality in narratives across languages. It was found that speakers of all languages rely on the same set of strategies in order to capitalize on the hearer?s ability to infer bits that haven?t been explicitly said. However, a surprising amount of variation was discovered in terms of both the overall level of explicitness and the relative frequencies of the strategies of implicitness.

Another experiment was motivated by research in the field of social psychology, which suggests that members of societies that value self-determination/fulfillment over social commitments weigh an agent?s intentions more when attributing responsibility than members of societies that value social commitments higher. It was confirmed that there appear to be significant cultural differences in the conceptualization of the responsibility of accidental agents. However, the distribution of this effect over populations aligned only partially with the predictions in terms of the egocentric-sociocentric dichotomy. This research is ongoing.
